text:
<!here> just as a headsup – in the student portal materials it's mentioning "class" components vs. "functional" components, you can pretty much ignore this division since class components are for most intents and purposes outdated and the React world has moved on from it.

Every once in a while, you might see a piece of code that still uses class components just like you see some code still using var but most people writing React nowadays just use functions + hooks because it's the better paradigm :man-shrugging:

elements.text:
just as a headsup – in the student portal materials it's mentioning "class" components vs. "functional" components, you can pretty much ignore this division since class components are for most intents and purposes outdated and the React world has moved on from it.

Every once in a while, you might see a piece of code that still uses class components just like you see some code still using var but most people writing React nowadays just use functions + hooks because it's the better paradigm

text:
I just like functions way more then classes...
I did the tic-tac-toe game in the docs and was like "oh no, react has classes all over the place?!" :this-is-fine:

elements.text:
I just like functions way more then classes...
I did the tic-tac-toe game in the docs and was like "oh no, react has classes all over the place?!"

text:
yeah, they used to have classes everywhere and it was a pain – hence they changed to hooks :man-shrugging:

pretty much a year or so after I learned React, the change happened... but there are still many tutorials and stuff out there not using hooks and old codebases that haven't updated / changed their stuff.

what's even worse, React is probably changing paradigms going forward again at some point, leading to even more confusion :man-shrugging:

elements.text: yeah, they used to have classes everywhere and it was a pain – hence they changed to hooks

pretty much a year or so after I learned React, the change happened... but there are still many tutorials and stuff out there not using hooks and old codebases that haven't updated / changed their stuff.

what's even worse, React is probably changing paradigms going forward again at some point, leading to even more confusion

text: because the old stuff usually still works, it's just less beautiful and easy to handle/manage doing complex stuff with it ... so it sticks around

elements.text: because the old stuff usually still works, it's just less beautiful and easy to handle/manage doing complex stuff with it ... so it sticks around

text: So one more time :this-is-fine:

elements.text: So one more time

text: ^^ it's just like JS in this regard. people learn from their mistakes, but they don't want to update ALL of the code they written with their "flawed" assumptions... Hence many don't :man-shrugging:

elements.text: ^^ it's just like JS in this regard. people learn from their mistakes, but they don't want to update ALL of the code they written with their "flawed" assumptions... Hence many don't

text: How do you handle all your node_modules-folders? Do you keep them, because :man-shrugging: or do you delete them in older (or small) projects and run npm install if you ever have to check them out again?

text: big problem, usually if I run out of space I delete node_modules.

text: you can write/find some little shell helper that does this stuff for you. Walking down projects folders (if you keep them nice and tidy in one place like you should) and then rm -rf node_modules for each of them.

text:
in case you want the node_modules script here you go
<https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42950501/delete-node-modules-folder-recursively-from-a-specified-path-using-command-line>

attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: Delete node_modules folder recursively from a specified path using command line
attachments.title: Delete node_modules folder recursively from a specified path using command line
attachments.text: I have multiple npm projects saved in a local directory. Now I want to take backup of my projects without the node_modules folder, as it is taking a lot of space and can also be retrieved any time...

elements.text: in case you want the node_modules script here you go

text: ```find . -name 'node_modules' -type d -prune -exec rm -rf '{}' +```
be careful with bash.

elements.text: be careful with bash.

text: do backups.

elements.text: do backups.

text: dry run would be this.

elements.text: dry run would be this.

text:
```find . -name 'node_modules' -type d -prune```
I hope :man-shrugging:

elements.text: I hope
